33.words: Artificial intelligence is one of those key pieces that has made it possible now to do driverless vehicles where it wasn't possible 10 years ago, particularly in the ability to see and understand scenes. A lot of people don't know this, but it's remarkably hard for computers until very, very recently to do even the most basic visual tasks like seeing a picture of a person and knowing that it's a person. And we've made gigantic strides with artificial intelligence and being able to see and understanding tasks, and that's obviously fundamental to being able to understand the world around you with the sensors that you have available. I think that you'll see the first vehicles operating with no one inside, them moving freight, in the next few years. And then you're going to see that expanding to more freight, more geographies, more weather over time as that capability builds up. We're talking less than half a decade.

35.words: This is one of the most remarkable stories in US labor history, I think, is the decline of unionized trucking. The industry was deregulated in 1980 and at that time truck drivers were earning the equivalent of over a hundred thousand dollars in today's dollars. And today the typical truck driver will earn a little over $40,000 a year. I think it's an important part of the automation story. Why are they so afraid of automation? Because we've had four decades of rising inequality in wages, and if anybody is going to take it on the chin from automation in the trucking industry, the first in line, it's going to be the driver without a doubt.

62.words: I was thinking a couple of things. I think first, at the end it just goes, oh, they retired the fleet in 2023. Why? I want to know more about that. I think it was really interesting, because the premise of the documentary is like AI is this huge thing and it's actually taking over trucking, but also they just retired the fleet and I don't know why. I'm curious about that. I would probably want to look it up. But I also saw that it said this is a cut version of the documentary, so I assume it would go over it more. But I think that generally what resonated with me is kind of this struggle between automation and safety and then also losing jobs. Because I think outside of driving, AI has kind of become this like, oh my God, it's rising and we're losing everything. And I think that's necessarily probably true, but the way my brain works because I'm interested in policy and things like that is okay, let's say AI does rise, how do we stop gap this loss of jobs? And so it reminds me of a couple of things. I was just with a friend, 'cause we had this debate competition, we were talking about universal basic income. And that's something I had been thinking about a lot with AI, specifically this idea that if we're going to consistently lose, and it's what you would call the low skilled, which isn't necessarily true, but that's just the name we have for it, jobs to automation, how do you stop gap that? Especially because these people are talking about they're barely paid anything when they do have their jobs, what about when they don't? And I think universal basic income was something that was kind of tossing around in my mind as something that might actually need to become a reality if AI continues to rise. But those are kind of my initial thoughts. I feel like if I watch something like this and it was kind of short, I'd then spend the next 15, 20 minutes just Googling things. 'Cause I don't know, I'm like that, I needed to know more.

68.words: I was going to say two things really quickly that I think Victoria and Brianna brought up that are really interesting, 'cause it was reminding me of this idea. What is an AI going to make the decision of? It reminds me of this game that was created by literally MIT called Moral Machine and it was to collect data on what humans think is the most moral for an autonomous driving car. So it would do things like, oh, if this car has to crash into someone, make the decision, should it crash into an elderly woman or an elderly man, things like that. And A, that's scary, like what? But B, I think it's interesting, 'cause there was something the truck driver said in the video, which was really, I think it hit home for me where he was like, "Yeah, all of this is human made and humans make mistakes." And I think that that's really important because we kind of have this veneer of objectivity with AI that, oh my God, it's a hundred percent safer. And that's what Alex Rodrigues was saying in the video, this is how you cut traffic collisions and traffic deaths. And maybe he's true, maybe there's some truth, or he's right, there's some truth in this fact that it might be safer. But I think that's also why we've had so many issues with algorithms being racist, being sexist, things like when Alexa and voice recognition was developed, it didn't recognize female voices because we only had male engineers on the team, things like that. I think we get so caught up with endless advancement that we don't remember that we are humans and we're making this technology and we're still wrong a bunch. And so it was kind of scary to see this guy be like, "Yeah, it's totally cool." And that's why I was nodding a lot when Zahed was like, "It sounds like a Silicon Valley dude who got a bunch of money and decided he had proof of concept he could do it." Because I was like, yeah, that sounds right. I think that there wasn't a lot of backing and the golf cart was very silly to me. I'm not going to lie. I was like, okay, it's a golf cart. I could drive a golf cart when I was 12, that doesn't mean I can drive a 48 wheeler. You know what I mean? And I think the other thing that Brianna brought up that was really, really interesting was the CO2 emissions because I think that's something that AI has popped up and no one thinks about, because the way AI works, it's not just something happening in the cloud. There's a bunch of servers that are working overtime. And so when you create all of these things that say powered by AI, not even trucking, but when you open Google Docs and it's like, do you want to write this thing with AI? All of that takes so much computing power. It's the same thing with NFTs where everyone was like, NFTs are really bad for the environment because all of that computing power is actually screwing up our environment. And I think that's also really important, because when you de-link the impacts of AI to what AI actually is or the real world practical, this is what it's doing to our environment, everyone's like, oh, this is cool. Even if it's creating things that aren't that great, at least it's creating something. But no, there's this idea, again, like what Brianna, what Victoria, what everyone was saying is do we actually need infinite progress or is there a second, we should take a step back and say, "Hey, maybe this isn't cool." I don't know. That's kind of what I was thinking about.

70.words: I can jump in. My debate coach has always talked about AI. He always calls it ChatGTP, and he always says that it is going to ruin the world basically. He's very defeatist and pessimistic about it. And it's an attitude that I hear a lot from people in Gen X and older generations and it really kind of bothers me. And we've talked about it a lot and debated about it a lot, and that he's kind of just like Pandora's Box has been opened and AI is going to do all these things. Not make robots that are going to kill us or whatever, but just take all our jobs and ruin all this stuff. And I think that a lot of people's attitude with AI is very much like it's out so it's already over. And that attitude is just so frustrating to me because it's like what happened to solving problems? Yes, AI does cool things that people like, but we did all those things before AI, we can do them again. And so I think one of the bigger problems with AI is people who just see it and say, "That's it. Game over. We're done. Our jobs are done, everything's done." And if we can actually focus on the fact that we actually do know how to drive trucks without computers and we can make art ourselves and we can write things ourselves, we don't have to just accept that AI is taking all our jobs. We can actually do those things without it. So I don't like pessimism.

78.words: There was something I was thinking about that I thought was kind of unrelated to the video, but the more you guys were speaking about it, the more I was like, no. There was this YouTube video I watched a couple of days ago. It was actually by this guy named Drew Gooden, which is funny because he's a commentary YouTuber and he does a bunch of silly stuff. So you would think he doesn't talk about serious things like this, but he just made this video, I think it was called AI is Ruining the Internet. And it started off very funny, oh, here's how AI is ruining our brains, things like that. But then he started making some very interesting points about how AI is essentially devaluing human creation and art, and this idea that we can just feed a computer all of these things and it'll produce art. He opens Getty stock images and this place where you're supposed to get things like a picture of a police car or a picture of a tree, you would also be seeing people selling AI generated images for 80 bucks. And it was like, what's going on? We're devaluing what we understand human contribution to be, especially ironic because the way AI works is you have to feed them human contribution. You have to show them, here's all of these examples of human art and human creation, now go make something that's inherently less valuable because it's just kind of an amalgamation of all these things. And so when we're thinking about the documentary, and I was kind of thinking... In the beginning, I was kind of like, oh, trucking, maybe I get it. 'Cause I don't know about you, when I'm on the freeway and I'm surrounded by four four wheelers, I'm like, okay, I have to lock in because I don't know what's going on. I'm driving a super tiny car and I'm really scared. And I was like, okay, maybe it would be better if it was automated. 'Cause I think also, I'm from California and I have family friends who work in Silicon Valley, and so I'm probably more open to technology like that than a lot of people. But then also when you kind of see the human contribution side, when you're talking to this trucker family that shows, I don't know, I guess I never really considered trucking as an industry where people put their heart and soul into. But then she was like, we pay this much for gas and we do this for the parts, and he's sleeping in the car. I think that was really interesting to me because it kind of shifted my perspective from the purely non-emotional, yeah, it's bad, the jobs are getting taken away, to also this is something that someone can take as much ownership of as creating art. Right? It's just as important. I think I never really likened to the two, but seeing the humanity behind it, I think in that sense it changed my mind. I was always pretty like, no, taking jobs is pretty bad, but I think that it's shown a new aspect of it for me. Also, Brianna, the Facebook, the nonstop AI generated pictures, I think that's how that video started and I was like, oh, this is stupid. It's hilarious, but it's stupid. And then I was reading more about it and I was like, this is scary. This is really bad. But, yeah.

20.words: After the 737 Max crash in Indonesia, the FAA learned it was possible some systems in the Boeing 737 Max could fail. Later, when explaining their decision not to ground the plane, they said the chance was as close to zero as their calculations allowed, considering the number of planes in the air. That choice prompted a congressional investigation in 2018, and ultimately led to changes in how the FAA certifies planes. Back in 2024, after the Alaska Airlines incident, the FAA immediately grounded other similar 737 Max planes for inspection.

35.words: In a statement, Boeing said it is dedicated to transparency, and it is implementing a comprehensive plan to strengthen safety and quality. Less than seven weeks after the Alaska Air incident, the executive running the Max program was axed. Later, in March of 2024, the FAA said it found multiple quality control issues with the Max. 18.words: Okay. I think two things. So the first thing is when you kind of hear the words "child poverty" or "child hunger," you don't really think about the developed world. You're supposed to think about, "There are children dying in Africa," things like that, but I do think child poverty and child hunger in the US, but also in developed countries, is a really serious issue that a lot of people don't know about. So I actually appreciated that they took a specific look at that. I think the other thing I was thinking about, that was kind of interesting, was this idea that children who don't have food or they have food insecurity, get fed at school, because that's just something I've been paying attention to. In California, we have free lunch, but it was a whole thing, because everyone was like, "Oh. Why are we having free lunch for everybody?" Then, also we heard about Tim Waltz when he got nominated, and his whole thing, it wasn't his whole thing, but one of the biggest things he did was free lunch for Minnesota school children. And so, that was really interesting to me, because I think it's such an odd issue to be contentious about, but it just goes to show that people can argue about anything, so those are kind of the two things I was thinking about.

21.words: One thing I was thinking, like what Aiyushi said, is about how we don't really think about the developed world. Obviously, it's not like we don't assume that those problems existed, that there are those problems, because we're not naive. But the scale of a problem, something as simple as hunger, in a place where we have so much food and we know that we waste so much food, is kind of just crazy to think about if you haven't really experienced it firsthand, because it's just way bigger than you think it is. Even though we live in a rich country, one of the richest in the world with some of the most food, people still go hungry. It's kind of easy to forget about those people when you're thinking about the bigger problems that exist in other parts of the world.

Trying to process that, in my mind, that someone could think that just makes going into a conversation like this even more difficult, just the nature of the conversation, because of that reason, I don't know, that it just seems infuriating. I'm glad I've never had to try to change someone's mind, that children deserve food, nutritious food at that.

24.words: Well, I mean, I would say, I mean, do know what the con is, because I have seen it in discussions around these things, and the idea generally is that, I think you've mentioned this before, but it's the parents' fault for being poor, basically. I mean, also Martin mentioned that we don, we don't talk about poverty much in the developed world, but really we kind of do. I think I've seen it, maybe I've just seen it more than you have. We have two ways, generally, of categorizing poverty. One is, as Martin said, just kind of like, "Oh. It's somewhere out there, in Africa or wherever," whatever country is going through something right now, and so it's not really in our mind. The other one, the other way of thinking of poverty, is they deserve it, which is the two main narratives about poverty in the United States. People would be like, "I don't think the kid deserves it for being poor," but usually when it comes to the idea of pre-lunch and stuff, it's like, "Oh. The parents shouldn't be relying on things. That'll just keep them from taking responsibility," or something like that. I mean, that's generally how those conversations go. Personally, I haven't directly engaged too much. I don't really know what it looks like when someone like that changes their mind. I haven't seen it for myself. Yeah.

26.words: So I think it's a slow morning. It's taking me a little bit to process, but one of the things that I was kind of thinking about was, at least in my high school, I remember the switch to free lunch. I remember we used to pay for lunch, and they kind of had free or reduced lunch, and then everyone paid for lunch. I mean, didn't pay for lunch, like they passed a bill and it was free lunch. People were kind of like, "Oh. That's weird," but then it ended up being a really good thing, not only for the people who were food insecure, but then you had people who probably could afford food, but they were actually eating lunch for once in their lives. They weren't forgetting to eat, they weren't not packing food, because they realized, "Oh, it's there. Let me just go eat something," so it ended up being a net positive for everyone. I mean, other than just the baseline, "Yes, we should feed our kids," it was one of the most beneficial arguments to why we should provide this baseline. I think the other thing I was thinking about was, during COVID, when everything was shut down, schools became, at least in California, the place for people to get their food. They were still providing free lunch. They had drop-offs, they had places for people to come in and get their food, and I know because I had some people I know volunteer at the school, helping with distribution and helping make sure, and a lot of people actually came and grabbed food because this is what they relied on, and so I think that was really important. I have never really had a conversation with someone who is anti providing, not just kids free lunch, but I guess things like that, but what I do think is kind of funny is when this topic, like very recently with Tim Waltz, came in the mainstream, one of my favorite teachers I follow on Instagram, and he posted this thing about, it was just this joke. It was someone he was making fun of. He was like, "Who is going to pay for kids free lunch? Who's going to pay for kids free lunch?" He was like, "Me. I will pay for kids free lunch," because I think the issue is when people are arguing about, ""Why do my taxes have to be taken for your mistake? It was kind of reassuring to see that that's not the majoritarian narrative. There are a lot of people who are like, "Actually, no. This is important. We should pay for our kids' free lunch." As someone who is still a teenager, it was kind of scary for a second for a lot of people to be like, "Tim Waltz did something wrong." I was like, "What? That's crazy," so yeah, I think that was important. The last thing is, I know we're talking a lot about school lunches and things like that, which is important, but the other thing is I think child hunger and child poverty is such an issue in urban areas because of food deserts. I know in LA, a lot of people's closest grocery store is a liquor store. Some of my friends, I remember we wanted snacks, and so we would have to go walk to a liquor store nearby to grab snacks, and I was like, "That's crazy." I feel like that's also such an under, I don't want to say under-understood. I don't know what the word I'm looking for, I'm searching for right now, is part of the reason why we have so much food insecurity in the US.

28.words: I don't really know where to go with this, but I'm from South Dakota, we did not ever have free lunches for everybody. I just remember I was on the reduced lunches when I was younger, and I know that a lot of people talk about the stigma or whatever, like people are afraid to be on reduced lunches. I believe that we did have free lunches for everybody, but I do think that the argument about the stigma around free lunches or reduced lunches, it probably exists in some places, but I don't know. When I was a kid, people didn't know if you had free or reduced lunches. Those programs don't create a second class of lunch eaters. I don't know. I really don't know where I'm going with this, other than to say that even free and reduced lunches, people argue against those. I just don't understand how. I really don't, and I know [Zahad] explained the cons, but I don't want to get into one of those conversations, because I would get too angry and I don't understand the other side. I don't see any downsides.

29.words: I mean, to me, the cons are just having a lack of empathy. That's kind of what it feels like, and so it's like, "Okay." I think the interesting thing that, Martin, you're talking about, it kind of reminds me of there's an argument about universal basic income, and people are always like, "Why are we giving this to everybody? There are a lot of rich people that don't need universal basic income," and one of the arguments for it is, if you only give it to some people, there's kind of this AIDS stigma like, "Oh. We're giving you handouts," versus if you give it to everybody, that stigma kind of goes away. I don't know if I've ever seen it for free and reduced lunch, but I could see that being a problem, because kids are mean, and so if you're getting free and reduced lunch and people are like, "Oh, she's poor," or whatever, at least if you give it to everyone, that could be a benefit of taking that away.

30.words: I will say, when it comes to universal basic income, any remotely feasible plan would increase taxes on the rich by far more than whatever they gain by basic income, but I think, in general, so I think you said lack of empathy, and I think that's definitely part of the reason, but I think the other part of the reason is that lack of empathy, I think that means that a lot of, especially when it comes to American narratives around wealth and such, the idea is that if you're richer, you deserve it. You did something to get up to where you are. But the flip side of that, the natural flip side, the unavoidable flip side is that, if you are poor, then you have failed to do something or you've done something wrong and such. I mean, maybe from an outside perspective, you can say, "Okay, sure. I choose not to believe that," as something. I feel like I think most of us would choose not to believe that, but the issue then is that if you try and take that, if you do decide to take that and run with it, you kind of end up running into a lot of other foundational kind of assumptions about America and its economic system and such, which is why people, I think, are generally unwilling to do that.

31.words: So I was having a conversation with my debate coach, Mr. Conda, about something similar a couple of months ago, and he was talking about how he grew up extremely poor and super small town South Dakota. 35.words: I don't think it changed my thoughts, I think primarily because it didn't bring up much new information, other than the racial disparity, but it actually did make me think of something. Yesterday, I was helping my friends pick his classes. He's at UCLA orientation today, and they just started this new minor called food studies, and it's literally about this. The description is, "In the world, there are 1 billion people who are underfed, and then 1.5 billion people who are overweight. How did we mess up our food distribution this bad, and what can we do to fix it?" To me, I was like, "Oh. That sounds really interesting," but also, I think it's an indication that we are starting to, as a society, understand that this is a real issue like food distribution, and not like we never realized child poverty was an issue, but I think there's just more of a passion. But for me, personally, I feel like some of the arguments that I've heard, because I feel like I've had those conversations even with some members of my community, is that it feels like, sorry, I got distracted by [Ritika]'s, is that a dog? Where is the dog? Oh, so cute. Oh, I actually forgot what I was going to say. That dog was really cute. Anyway, I think some people, another I guess argument that some people would bring up in conversations is that people become dependent on handouts, like when they're offered free resources or reduced resources. I guess this all goes back to the American dream narrative, that I think Zahad had mentioned, which is that if you work hard, then you're going to have a good life. That's the whole premise of, we're in a country of opportunity, and so if you're here and you're willing to be able to work every single day, and you're not going to take no for an answer, at the end, you're going to win in life. For example, poverty wouldn't even be something that's on your path. That kind of made me think about people who supposedly have made it, and obviously, I think in their life they've had a lot of different opportunities and people who are willing to support them to get there as well, but what's interesting is that oftentimes when I talk to these people, kind of at their prime, at a time where they don't really have to worry about poverty as much anymore, they kind of start having this different mentality, which is that, "I made it here because I never relied on free or reduced resources. I made it here because I went to bed hungry. I was willing to wake up early every single day, and I went to work, and I didn't complain about it," so that was just something that I thought about when we were having the conversation, but is there anyone else who wants to make a connection?

49.words: Actually, the reason I made that face is because it reminded me of an exact conversation I had like that. It was a college interview. I know, I know, I know. The interviewer asked me like, "Oh. What's a project you've been working on?" So I was telling them about my work with legal aid and helping people get resources to get their citizenship, and he kind of looks at me, and he is like, "Why?" I was like, "My parents needed their citizenship, and I have a lot of family that did, and it was really," Brianna's face, Brianna's face, and by the way, this was not a white man. This was someone who was very clearly second generation, and I was explaining to him why. He goes, "Yeah, but my parents did it." Again, this is a college interview. I was like, "This is not where we're supposed to be having this issue. I was just telling you about what I do in my free time." He was like, "No," and he's a doctor, by the way, who graduated from Georgetown. Yeah, it was Georgetown. He was like, "Well, my parents figured it out, and so I'm sure they did too. Your parents probably figured it out. They did it without programs like yours." I was like, "Yeah, barely. They barely did it, and they were pretty well off, all things considered, so let's consider the people that aren't well off." And so, it was the most conversation I had had about this, because I think, Jessie, you kind of hit the nail on the head. It's like people start with this empathy, and then they kind of do it, and there's slowly this ideological shift, where they're like, "Well, I did it by myself, so you should do it by yourself too." It's kind of like how people were so against student loan forgiveness, because they paid off their own student loans. I was like, "That's crazy." It's kind of like a sinking ship mentality, like take everyone down with me. I don't know. I think it's one of the most frustrating things about current American politics, where there's this very individualistic view of what a person should be able to do for themselves, but the issue is A, that's harming everyone else around them, and B, it's harming people who had no say in the decision, like kids who couldn't afford lunch, and they're also not supposed to be working full-time jobs. Why are we punishing them? I mean, I would go so far as to say, why are we punishing their parents too? But even on a base level, why are we punishing them? It's crazy to me. It's obscene. I don't understand it.

48.segment_words: It's kind of like how people were so against student loan forgiveness, because they paid off their own student loans.

This is, as you said, the American dream type thing, right? I mean, that's kind of what that means. I mean, the American dream is, inherently, an individualistic type of thing, and we've seen it. I think it's not surprising whatsoever that, generally, people who are richer are more conservative. I think that's a pretty consistent trend. I don't think that's a new thing and, in general, it is hard to try and get that into someone, because the flip side of that is that people have justified pride in their own accomplishments. I think part of that is that making that easier for other people, or creating more resources and such, kind of a little bit diminishes that idea, just from what I've seen like, "Oh, I did it, because it was hard.
